importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Ostwall complex was abandoned by the Nazis in 1945, marking the end of its military use and beginning its transition into a site of historical and tourist interest.
The London Tunnels are expected to open as a tourist attraction in 2028, following a $149 million transformation, linking Cold War history to modern tourism.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Nazi construction of the Ostwall complex occurred during the 1930s–1945, a period of intense militarization and underground warfare planning.
The timeline of the London Tunnels' transformation and opening in 2028 reflects a contemporary revival of Cold War-era infrastructure as a cultural and tourist asset.

keyTakeAways: The Ostwall, a 20-mile underground Nazi complex in Poland, is now a dark tourism destination with 19 miles open to the public in the Międzyrzecz Fortified Region Museum.
The Passage of Commodus in Rome, a 1,800-year-old tunnel linked to Emperor Commodus, is opening to the public and is tied to a historical assassination attempt.
The London Tunnels, built during WWII to shelter citizens, are being redeveloped into a $149 million tourist attraction, inspired by MI6’s Special Operations Executive and the James Bond Q Branch.
Kayaköy in Turkey, abandoned after the Greco-Turkish war, is now a ghost town and eerie tourist site with a three-euro entry fee.
Babylon in Iraq, a historic Mesopotamian city, remains a site of archaeological significance despite overgrown ruins and limited facilities.
West Virginia's Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum, once overcrowded and controversial, is now a macabre tourist attraction where visitors experience its dark history and paranormal claims.

namedEntities.name: Ostwall
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 20-mile underground Nazi military complex built in Poland and abandoned in 1945, now a dark tourism destination.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Ostwall is central to the article as a real, physical example of Nazi underground military infrastructure and its modern transformation into a tourist attraction.

namedEntities.name: Pniewo
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A small village in Poland near which the Ostwall is located.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pniewo is the geographic context for the Ostwall, providing the location and setting that tie the underground complex to a real-world village.

namedEntities.name: Międzyrzecz Fortified Region Museum
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A museum in Poland that opens 19 miles of tunnels from the Ostwall to the public.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It represents the modern, educational, and tourism-focused reclamation of the abandoned Nazi tunnel system.

namedEntities.name: Passage of Commodus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 1,800-year-old Roman tunnel in Rome linked to Emperor Commodus, believed to be where he narrowly escaped an assassination attempt.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It connects ancient Roman history with a dramatic historical event and is opening to public visitors, adding historical depth to the article.

namedEntities.name: Emperor Commodus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Roman emperor known for his cruelty and a character in the film 'Gladiator'.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Commodus is relevant as the historical figure tied to the assassination attempt in the tunnel, making the site more engaging for modern audiences.

namedEntities.name: London Tunnels
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A mile-long series of underground chambers in London built during WWII for civil shelter and later used by Britain’s Special Operations Executive.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The London Tunnels are a key focus of the article as a Cold War-era underground site being redeveloped into a major tourist destination.

namedEntities.name: Special Operations Executive (SOE)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A British intelligence agency during WWII, considered the real-life inspiration for James Bond’s Q Branch.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The SOE’s use of the tunnels links the underground site to espionage and Cold War history, enhancing its relevance and appeal.

namedEntities.name: Kayaköy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A former town in Turkey abandoned after the Greco-Turkish war, now a ghost town.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kayaköy serves as a parallel example of a deserted town with historical and eerie appeal, illustrating the broader theme of abandoned sites as tourist destinations.

namedEntities.name: Babylon
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An ancient Mesopotamian city in modern-day Iraq, once a central hub of civilization.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Babylon represents ancient history and cultural heritage, showing how ruins can remain significant despite being in disrepair.

namedEntities.name: Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A West Virginia asylum that operated in the 19th and 20th centuries and is now a macabre tourist attraction.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It exemplifies how former institutions of suffering can be repurposed as sensationalized tourist experiences.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores a range of underground and abandoned historical sites around the world, highlighting their transformation into tourist attractions. Central to the narrative is the Ostwall, a sprawling Nazi bunker complex in Poland built during WWII and now open to the public as part of a dark tourism initiative. Other key features include the Roman Passage of Commodus, where Emperor Commodus narrowly escaped an assassination, the London Tunnels being redeveloped into a $149 million Cold War-era tourist attraction, the abandoned Turkish ghost town Kayaköy, and the ancient ruins of Babylon in Iraq. Additionally, the Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum in West Virginia is presented as a macabre example of how former institutions can be repurposed as paranormal and historical experiences. Together, these sites illustrate the global trend of repurposing forgotten or dark history into modern, accessible, and often sensationalized travel experiences.
title: Deep underground, the Nazis built a city for thousands of soldiers. Now it’s a tourist attraction
